title: I rode a scooter home
content: We’re currently a single car family. Laura sold her car to Carvana before we left for Colorado. I had a haircut scheduled at the same time she had to drive to a lunch, so she dropped me off. It was close enough that I could walk home, but far enough to justify hopping on an electric scooter. I hadn’t been on one for years and didn’t have the app anymore, but within a couple of minutes I was on my way home. Navigation while riding is still a problem, which is a bit crazy. There’s no place to put my phone and looking at my watch takes a hand off the scooter, which isn’t ideal. Electric scooters are much too slow to be sharing roads with cars, especially in Los Angeles. I had to be on a major thoroughfare for a few blocks and it was a bit harrowing. While I can’t imagine riding a scooter that does 60+ (they do exist apparently!), a top speed of 40 feels like a good top speed. I say all of this knowing nothing about electric scooters.
author: bradbarrish
